Rationale  Coal-fired thermal power plants are the main source of energy in Gansu

However,  clean  energy  production  is  unevenly  distributed  and  faces 
many challenges in Gansu.

Zhangye City’s 1.25 million population, almost 80% are classified as rural. 
Of its rural population, 293,000 or about 23% have incomes less than the

17,000 persons in Zhangye City can be classified as urban poor. Located 
about 600 kilometers northwest from the provincial capital of Lanzhou, 
the City experiences frequent interruptions and shortages in electricity 
supply. The Zhangye City electric network is part of the Hexi corridor 
network,  which  in  turn  is  part  of  the  Gansu  and  Northwest  power

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Economic and social development in PRC has been rapid in the last two decades. The 
PRC’s gross domestic product (GDP) per capita was $964 (in 2002 values), life expectancy at 
birth is 70.1 years, and adult literacy is 83%. Government programs have resulted in poverty 
reduction, particularly in rural areas. Using the official rural poverty line of CNY947 per capita, 
the PRC’s rural poor represents 4.6% of the rural population. Studies estimate urban poverty in 
the PRC at 4.7%. 
 
3.  Economic  growth  has  been  facilitated  by  infrastructure  development,  a  crucial 
component being energy sector development. At the end of 2002,  the PRC’s total installed 
power was 350 gigawatts (GW). By 2010, it is estimated that total installed capacity will reach 
450 GW. The PRC's electricity is generated overwhelmingly by coal (about 75%). Coal use in 
the  PRC  entails  high  transport  costs  and  is  characterized  by  low  utilization  efficiency. 
Hydroelectricity ranks a distant second (about 20%), followed by oil, gas, and nuclear power, 
which account for the remaining 5%. Appendix 2 gives a summary analysis for the energy 
sector.  
 
4.  The  heavy  dependence  on  coal  as  an  energy  source  has  resulted  in  substantial 
environmental damage due to pollution. The adverse impacts of environmental pollution have 
been acknowledged to disproportionately affect the poor. Poorer households typically rely on 
raw coal and biomass (e.g., wood and animal dung) for cooking and heating, and suffer 
accordingly from indoor air pollution. High pollution loads and energy intensity would be reduced 
if there were a more pronounced shift toward clean energy, energy efficiency, and greenhouse 
gas abatement.  
 
5.   Coal-fired thermal power plants are the main source of energy in Gansu province; 
however, hydropower accounted for 41% of power generation in  2000. Gansu is developing 
several clean energy development initiatives, covering a wide spectrum of renewable energy 
technologies. Installed wind generating capacity is 8 megawatts (MW). Residential solar water 
heaters are becoming more common. Solar photovoltaic and battery systems are used in some 
remote, off-grid areas as source of power for small appliances (e.g., radio and television).1 
Biomass-to-biogas is another potential source of clean energy for agricultural areas. Different 
technologies have regional applications within the Province, with solar and wind appearing more 
promising in the western areas, and greater hydropower potential in the southeastern areas. 
Several small and medium-scale hydropower projects have been commissioned in the region of 
the Project, with several more planned for development. However, clean energy production is 
unevenly distributed in Gansu. The capital, Lanzhou, has frequently been cited as one of the 
cities  with  the  worst  air  pollution  in  the  PRC,  mainly  arising  from  coal  combustion  and 
desertification.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
7.  Zhangye City3 is a poor area of Gansu with a deficient energy supply. It used to be a

less than the provincial rural poverty line. Using the lower range of provincial estimates it is 
estimated that 17,000 can be classified as urban poor in Zhangye City. A summary of Zhangye 
City’s approach to poverty reduction is given in Supplementary Appendix A, and a summary of 
the public consultation process is given in Supplementary Appendix B. Located about 600 
kilometers (km) northwest  of the provincial capital of Lanzhou (Map 1), the  city experiences

part of the Hexi corridor network, which in turn is part of the Gansu and Northwest power

10.  The  98 MW  Xiaogushan  hydropower  plant  (XHP)  is  the  least-cost  alternative  for

11.  The development of clean energy is consistent with the PRC Government’s 10th Five-
Year Plan, which calls for energy sector restructuring. The plan’s target is to decrease the 
proportion  of  energy  from  coal  by  3.9%  and  increase  energy  from  natural  gas  and

Zhangye City (91% of installed capacity). A review of the clean energy subsector, and key

improvement have also been substantial.  
 
12.  The development of clean energy resulting in increased energy generation and in more 
reliable and efficient energy service contributes to poverty reduction. Poverty reduction in 
Zhangye  City  is  governed by the strategy put forward in the “Overall Program of Poverty 
Reduction and Development in Gansu Province (2001–2010)”, developed by the  provincial 
government. The plan identifies the extreme natural conditions, poor infrastructure, and low 
levels of human capital as the causes of continued poverty in the Province. Hence the areas of 
focus  are:  infrastructure  development  particularly  rural  roads,  electricity  supply,  and 
communications;  increased  agricultural  productivity  focused  on  irrigation  improvement; 
environmental  protection,  rehabilitation,  and  improvement  of  existing  infrastructure;  and 
improvement of the delivery of social services.

14.  Power utilities have been weak in the area of commercial and financial management. 
Often, there is a need for institutional strengthening in the areas of organizational structure,

15.  ADB reviewed and evaluated the cost-recovery performance of the power sector in 
14 developing member countries (DMCs), and reviewed the record of financial covenants by 42 
power  utilities.6  Through  three  key  criteria—cost  minimization,  tariff  setting,  and  collection

satisfactory performance. Among the lessons in the review of compliance levels, the need to 
assist  DMCs  to  create  new  institutions  with  a  more  business-like  approach  to  utility 
management was noted. ABD support should continue for new, unbundled utilities that have 
adopted a more transparent, commercial, and independent approach. 
 
16.  The  above  lessons  have  been  taken  into  account  in  designing  the  Project.  A 
comprehensive  feasibility  study  was  prepared  during  the  study  process,  and  project 
implementation issues were given special emphasis. Consulting services will be provided to 
assist in project implementation, and institutions involved will be strengthened to improve overall 
and financial management capabilities, and to ensure sustainability. Local currency financing 
was structured to ensure an appropriate mix of debt and government equity. Provision was 
made  for  sufficient  working  capital,  and  sensitivity  analysis  of  financial  and  economic 
performance was undertaken. Conservative cost contingencies have been used to avoid loan 
surpluses. Technical aspects were carefully reviewed and project alternatives were examined 
prudently. Project design has carefully considered environmental and social aspects and has 
ensured that the Project is consistent with ADB’s energy and environment policies.

1.  Demand Analysis 
 
51.  The load forecast period for the Gansu network was divided into two terms: short-term 
(3 years) and long-term  (to  the  end  of  the system planning period  in 2020).  A  bottom-up 
approach or  sector analysis method was used for the short-term forecast. Different end-use 
demands—primary  (agriculture),  secondary  (industry  and  construction),  tertiary  (including 
commercial and service), and residential (urban and rural)—were calculated based on current 
economic  activities,  policies,  and  impact  of  recent  major  construction  projects  in  Gansu 
province. Three methods—regression, linear time series, and exponential time series—were 
used for forecasting energy consumption.  The regression model used electricity tariff, gross 
domestic  product,  population,  industry  structure,  and  energy  efficiency  as  independent 
variables. The historical data from 1986 to 2001 and the short-term demand information (2002–
2004) were all taken as inputs to the regression model. The estimates of the exponential time 
series (GWh 89,788) and regression models (GWh 90,083) were similar, whereas the linear 
time series produced a different trend. The analysis used the estimate from the regression 
model and rejected the results from  the linear time series  (Appendix 13 and Supplementary 
Appendix J).  
 
2.  Least-Cost Analysis 
 
52.  Because  of  the  large  gap  between  demand  (1,400–2,000 GWh)  and  supply  (750–
1,200 GWh) in Zhangye City, demand-side responses were not considered as full alternatives in 
the analysis. Only supply-side options—new generation plants—were used as viable options. 
Five initial alternatives using three power generation technologies—hydropower, coal-fired, and 
natural-gas-fired—were preliminarily considered for selecting viable electricity generation for the 
province. Three fossil fuel generation technologies were considered as technology alternatives: 
coal-fired thermal (small 300 MW and large 600 MW), and combined-cycle gas turbine (CCGT 
300 MW). Technology alternatives, including XHP, were analyzed in detail. Capital and annual 
operation and maintenance (O&M) costs for each technology alternative were examined. The 
hydropower and coal-fired power stations were the only two options that showed a positive net 
present value (using a 12% discount rate). The larger hydropower option was not considered in 
detail due to project schedule and hydrologic restrictions; the CCGT option was dropped due to 
the lack of natural gas in the project area. 
 
53.  For direct comparability, the output of each alternative was normalized. Adjustments 
were also made for load factor differences. It was assumed that aside from the benefit for 
capacity substitution for XHC, the alternatives would generate more energy (the load factor is 
around 68%) to substitute generation from small coal-fired plants. The latter could not be used 
to meet incremental demand, but would save fuel consumption in existing plants, bringing

15
energy savings benefits. The equalizing discount rate—the rate at which the present value of 
two life-cycle cost streams are equal—thus indicating a discount rate at which preference 
changes—shows  that  hydropower  remains  a  better  alternative  up  to  the  discount  rate  of 
12.85%, after which smaller thermal power units will be preferable. Hydropower, with its high 
capital costs and very low operational costs, is the preferred option when lower discount rates 
are used (Appendix 13).  
 
54.  Using viable technological options—hydropower and coal-fired plants—a list of feasible 
power plant alternatives was developed, subject to the constraints imposed by the environment, 
river flow, and geography/geology. Various hydropower candidates were considered (including 
few-MW small hydropower stations up to large stations such as the 1,400 MW Heishanxia 
station). The development sequence for these hydropower candidates before 2010 has been 
designated as “fixed scheme”, because either they are under construction or there have been 
other development purposes (flood control and water supply).  XHP is the only candidate for 
power expansion in the period up to 2010 and others, except fixed ones, will be available after 
2010.  
 
55.  The  Generation  Expansion  System  Planning  (GESP)  II  model  developed  by  Power 
Economic Research Institute of Beijing was used to identify the least-cost alternative generation 
option from the list of feasible alternatives based on the  demand forecast for  the Gansu power 
system. The least-cost analyses confirmed the robustness of XHP. The GESP II model optimized the 
objective function of minimum total system cost—capital costs, operational costs, and other external 
costs—to meet power demand within the defined reliability criteria. The planning period used was 
2002 to 2020 and, in order to reflect the operation characteristics of expansion candidates sufficiently, 
the study period was expanded to 2050. The technical and economic indices of the power system 
from 2021 to 2050 were assumed to be same with those in 2020. 
 
56.  Three hydrologic conditions were considered: average with 80% probability, wet with 10% 
probability, and dry with 10% probability. The production simulation was carried out for all hydrologic 
conditions.  The  least-cost  analysis  used  the  weighted  average  operations  cost  based  on  the 
probabilities in the objective function. The forecast annual load curve was modeled using three 
seasons: wet season (April to September), average season (October to December), and dry season 
(January to March). Based on historic data, the system peak was modeled in the dry season. The 
fixed system included existing power plants (under construction or decided generation plants, 
retirement plans of generation units, and power exchanges with other power grids. The GESP 
model  identified  the  98 MW  (351  GWh)  XHP  as  the  least-cost alternative for generation 
expansion in Gansu province (Appendix 13).  
 
3.  Economic Analysis 
 
57.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated for the Project to assess its 
economic viability (Appendix 14 and Supplementary Appendix K). The costs considered were 
capital costs, and O&M costs. Appropriate conversion factors were used to convert financial 
values into economic values. Values are expressed in 2003 local currency. The quantified 
benefits of the proposed projects considered in the economic analysis include incremental 
energy supply  through willingness-to-pay (WTP). The EIRR was computed at 23.4% for the 
Project. Environmental improvement, education, health, and other social benefits were not 
included in the economic analysis.13 Sensitivity and risk analyses were carried out simulating 
adverse scenarios, and the project EIRR was found to be stable and robust.

4.  Financial Analysis 
 
58.  The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) and financial net present value (FNPV) were 
estimated for XHC. The FIRR is 7.5%, higher than the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) 
estimated at 4.53%, and the FNPV is CNY152.4 million at  this WACC. The base case is 
considered financially feasible. Sensitivity analysis shows that the FIRR is robust under adverse 
conditions (Appendix 15 and Supplementary Appendix L). The financial viability in terms of 
equity capital and a tariff analysis have been undertaken and are shown in Appendix 16 and 
Supplementary Appendix M.  
 
59.  An electricity tariff of CNY0.26 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) was assumed for the financial 
analysis. It is an ADB assumption based on the discussions with various officials. This rate is 
slightly lower than the tariff (CNY0.29/kWh) that XHC claims it would receive from the Zhangye 
Electricity Grid.  
 
60.  The FIRR measures the viability of a project. The XHC component’s receipts, payments, 
and net cash flows are for the full project period (24 years) where it is assumed that the receipts 
and payments will remain constant in real terms once a steady state is reached. The present 
value of net benefits becomes zero at a discount rate of 7.5%, which is the FIRR for the Project. 
Since the cash flows in the FIRR calculation are post-tax, the FIRR is compared against the 
post-tax WACC of 4.53%. Since the FIRR is higher than the WACC, the XHP component is 
financially viable. Sensitivity analysis shows that the FIRR remains robust when tested under 
various adverse conditions. 
 
B.  Environmental Benefits 
 
61.  The Project will improve the efficiency  and reliability of the electricity supply and will 
have significant positive environmental impacts in terms of avoided air pollution from alternative 
energy sources. This will have positive associated area, regional, and global impacts from 
avoided increases in air pollutants. The system planning and least-cost analysis shows that the 
alternative is a 109 MW coal-fired power plant. Based on this alternative, the avoided emissions 
were estimated at a yearly average of 240 tons, 1,910 tons, 1,500 tons, and 366,000 tons of 
particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and carbon dioxide, respectively. With almost 
no trees and shrubs on the riverside mountains along the river section, grass vegetation of only 
15% in the XHP site, with thin soil layers on top of riverside mountains not suitable for grazing, 
no threatened species of wildlife, and few residential settlements—the negative environmental 
impacts are minimal and can be mitigated. Proper construction; rational reuse and disposal of 
excavated  soil  and  rock;  proper  treatment  of  wastewater  during  project  construction;  and 
restoration of construction sites, temporarily occupied land, gravel mining and washing sites, 
and waste rock sites, will mitigate adverse environmental impacts. The improved reliability of 
electricity in the project area, ecosystem rehabilitation and expansion, and economic and social 
improvements will enhance the net environmental benefits from the Project. 
 
C.  Social and Poverty Reduction Benefits 
 
62.  Benefits to the poor will largely be in terms of increased economic opportunities. XHP 
construction is expected to generate peak employment of 3,000 people. During the O&M of the 
power plant, about 100 permanent staff will be employed (Appendix 17 and Supplementary 
Appendix N). In order to ensure that the hiring of construction labor will benefit local people, 
especially the poor and women, ADB  has requested XHC, the Zhangye Labor Bureau, and the 
Zhangye All-China Women’s Federation to jointly prepare a labor hiring and training plan for the

17
unskilled workforce and to ensure that contractors implement the plan. Project beneficiaries and 
the proportion of beneficiaries who are poor are identified in Appendix 17 and on this basis the 
poverty impact ratio was computed at 42%. XHC will also implement additional measures to 
benefit  local  communities,  including  (i) hiring  and  training  of  local  workers  for  project 
construction, (ii) provision of water supply for Bajiaowan village, (iii) allowing access to project 
facilities (e.g., medical emergencies, transportation, electricity supply), (iv) supporting purchases 
of local supplies and services for local communities, and (v) utilizing  local  work  teams  for 
upgrading existing roads. 
 
63.  A total of 98 MW of clean power in Zhangye will support the expansion of the industry 
and agriculture sectors in Zhangye. The rural electrification component can provide reliable 
electricity supply for three townships with a total population of 24,037, of whom 22,193 or 92.3% 
are poor, and will encourage new small and medium enterprises that will increase output and 
employment. The improved electricity will allow Xishui herders to buy crop residues from 
lowland farmers, pass them through electric chaff cutters to feed livestock through the winter, or 
stall-feed more livestock (e.g., cashmere goats penned to collect wool) year round. Reliable 
power would also allow households better access to information (reading at night and in winter, 
television, radio) leading to better social development of poor people in the project area. In the 
farmer townships of Huazhai and Anyang, the stable voltage and more reliable electricity may 
permit farmers to pump water from the irrigation canals to their higher fields thus increasing the 
croppable area and reducing the risk of low yields and crop failure. Improved electricity supply 
will allow households to process crops. It will allow farmer groups to invest in electric threshing 
and winnowing machinery—to allow farmers to go away a month earlier to work in seasonal 
construction. In Huazhai township, the improved electricity supply and stable voltage will allow a 
10-bed hospital to use its x-ray and ultrasound machine, presently idled to avoid damage due to 
power fluctuations. 
 
64.  XHC is also required to pay construction tax equal to 4.12% of annual expenditures, of 
which 2.0% goes to local government (i.e., Sunan county). This revenue stream to Sunan 
county would be in the order of CNY10 million annually, which can be used to improve social 
services and invest in economic development activities to reduce poverty in the county.  
 
D.  Assessment of Project Risks 
 
65.  XHC will have several types of risks, including geotechnical, hydrologic, and financial 
risks, and it has taken appropriate steps to avoid or minimize all of them. The most crucial risks 
are floods and powerhouse location. Site investigations have shown that the rocks underlying 
the XHP site are of high strength and low mass permeability. Most of the faults are oriented 
normal to the proposed tunnel alignment and should only affect a limited length of tunnel. A 
detailed assessment of hydrologic risks is given in Supplementary  Appendix O. A potential 
slope failure on the mountain slope above the powerhouse poses a risk to XHP. XHP is located 
in an area of active geo-morphological development with steep natural slopes and  deeply 
incised valleys. Above the powerhouse the rock is expected to have a strongly developed joint 
system including critical joints dipping out of the hill with possible clay infill. Landslide may occur 
as  a  result  of  a  triggering  mechanism,  such  as  a combination  of  sudden rainstorm  and 
earthquake. To overcome the risks, XHC agreed to construct an underground powerhouse.  
 
66.  Water use rights are an additional project risk. XHC has obtained a license to use the 
river  for  XHP.  There  is  a  comprehensive  plan  to  develop  additional  hydropower  capacity 
upstream in a cascade system. The Ministry of Water Resources and the National Development 
and Reform Commission approved a planning document that includes allocation of water rights

18  
in the river basin. The EA has obtained water user rights for operation of XHP from the Water 
Resource Bureau of ZCG.  
 
67.  Additional  intangible  risks  exist  due  to  ongoing  restructuring  of  the  power  sector. 
Generation assets will be separated from transmission and distribution, and market pricing of 
generated power will be introduced in stages. Increased competition in the power generation 
sector may depress wholesale electricity prices. In Zhangye City, the demand-supply imbalance 
is expected to persist for several more years, as reflected in the project financial analyses. 
Additional generating capacity is proposed for the Zhangye City area, primarily the 150 MW 
Longshou phase II hydropower plant (downstream of the project site). The 600 MW Pingliang 
coal-fired power plant, proposed for the Gansu grid, would meet some of the Zhangye City 
demand. Large natural gas-fired plants are not currently planned in Zhangye City.

A.  Clean Energy Subsector Review 
 
1.  Potential for Hydropower  
 
1.  Practically usable hydropower resources are located in the southwest, central, and 
northwest part of the country. The hydropower potential is estimated to be 378 gigawatts (GW) 
of which only 83 GW is currently utilized—which is about 24% of the total installed capacity 
making the People’s Republic of China (PRC) the third largest country in the world in terms of 
total installed hydropower capacity. The potential for small-scale hydropower is also large with 
potential in all regions of the PRC. It is estimated that, among over 2,000 counties in the whole 
country, more than 1,100 are suitable for building small-scale hydropower stations of over 10 
megawatts (MW). The total potential for medium and small hydropower resources is about 
139 GW. Most of these are located in the vast mountainous areas, which account for 70% of the 
country's total land area. The installed capacity of small hydropower amounted to over 19 GW 
and the annual electricity output of 64 terawatt-hours (TWh). Hydropower supplies electricity to 
300 million people in about 800 counties, covering nearly half of the country's area and 70% of 
the mountainous area.

green source of energy for the province. Supported by a loan from the Government of Spain, 
the Yumen Wind Power  Station, the largest in Gansu province, with an installed capacity of 
8 MW, is expected to generate about 19 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity per year. Gansu

B.  Lessons Learned 
 
5.  ADB’s experience in the PRC’s energy sector has shown that its projects are generally 
well planned and implemented smoothly. Executing agencies and implementing agencies have 
personnel with good technical skills and have made effective use of the training financed under 
ADB  loans  to  build  their  institutional  capacity.  Compliance  with  covenants  is  generally 
acceptable, although greater efforts are required to implement the policy-related covenants, 
particularly those relating to diversification of enterprise ownership at the micro level in line with 
project commitments and policy directions. The rigorous government screening of projects has a 
positive impact. Energy conservation projects have experienced some delays, mainly because 
of their complex multicomponent nature involving several implementing agencies in different 
provinces. Delays have also occurred for some projects in loan signing and loan effectiveness, 
as well as in procurement, construction, and commissioning. The Government is streamlining 
the multiple approval process to address these problems. 
 
6.  Power utilities have been weak in the area of commercial and financial management. 
Often, there is a need for institutional strengthening in the areas of organizational structure, 
delegation of authority, management, information and control systems, accounting and financial 
management, and personnel development and training. So far, four of 10 public power sector 
projects financed by ADB in the PRC have been completed; these are the Fuel Conversion 
Project,1 Shanxi Liulin Thermal Power Project,2 Hunan Lingjintan Power Project,3 and Henan 
Power Project.4 The project completion and project performance audit reports for these projects, 
where prepared,   indicate that they were implemented smoothly, and assess them all as 
generally  successful.  Some  cost  increases  as  well  as  minor  delays  were  noted. 
Recommendations  from  the  experience  gained  highlight  (i) the  need  to  improve  financial 
reporting; (ii) the need for more attention to environmental matters; (iii) the advisability of using 
larger boiler-turbine units; and (iv) the importance of capacity building, not only for project 
preparation, but also for training staff in operational and managerial aspects of power utility 
operations. A reevaluation of the Fuel Conversion Project, which was completed in December 
1999, revised the project rating downward to unsuccessful in economic terms and concludes 
that ADB-financed projects in the energy sector should not be narrowly focused on expected 
economic gains, which may not materialize, and should be rigorously screened to ensure that 
they are in line with ADB’s energy policy.5 Recently, some ongoing power projects in the PRC 
have  experienced  some  implementation  delays  in  meeting  procurement  and  construction 
deadlines. This is mainly due to the ongoing restructuring of the power sector and consequent 
change  in  the  “ownership”  of  the  projects.  Nevertheless,  the  overall  implementation 
performance of ADB’s energy portfolio in the PRC is satisfactory.6

C.  Building Block Approach for Tariff Calculation  
 
4.  A common method used by regulators to assess tariffs of monopoly assets is known as 
the building block method. This involves the addition of the various costs of a business to 
calculate revenue required for a business to be viable, and division by forecast quantities to 
calculate tariffs. The key components of the building blocks approach are: return on assets; 
depreciation; operation and maintenance expenses; and taxation—when post-tax Weighted 
Average Cost of Capital (WACC) is used for Return on Assets. 
 
5.  Return on Assets. It is the total return required for the asset to meet the investor’s 
opportunity cost, usually measured as the asset value times the cost of capital. Cost of capital is 
calculated by adding the cost of debt and cost of equity with the respective weights or use of 
WACC. 
 
6.  Return of Assets. It is the proportion of assets used for production of goods and 
services in the year, or depreciation. It is calculated by dividing historical asset value by the life 
of an asset. For XHC, a depreciation rate of 3.75%. 
 
7.  Operation and Maintenance Cost. A benchmark figure of CNY0.03/kWh (excluding 
depreciation) was used, which is consistent to similar projects. Considering the remoteness of 
the project area, adjustments were made in certain components of the operation costs.  
 
8.  Taxation. Analysis used a post-tax WACC for return on assets. No allowances were 
made for tax in the calculation, so it is added separately in the building block approach to 
calculate revenue requirement.

9.  At the feasibility stage projects are screened on the basis of cost estimates and the 
acceptable unit price range is CNY 7,000–10,000 per kilowatt (kW). Xiaogushan Hydropower 
Plant with about 8,200 CNY/kW project cost, and CNY0.26/kWh proposed tariff, is consistent

A.  Poverty Analysis  
 
1.  Poverty Profile of Project Area. Of Zhangye City’s 1.25 million population, almost 80% 
are classified as rural. Of its rural population, 293,000 or almost 30% have incomes less than 
the national rural poverty line of CNY1,100. Using the lower range of provincial estimates it is 
estimated that 17,000 can be classified as poor. Details of poverty incidence in Zhangye City 
can be found in Supplementary Appendix N.  
 
2.  Causes of Poverty. In the farming areas of Zhangye City, the main causes of poverty 
are related to low farm productivity, lack of supplemental income sources, and lack of education. 
This is aside from the harsh natural conditions, which includes high altitude  that limits the 
growing season to 80–170 frost-free days allowing only one field crop per year; poor soils and 
low rainfall; and inadequate irrigation. Many farmers have unreliable gravity irrigation and 
cannot use electricity to pump water from either an irrigation canal or from an aquifer of 
economic depth resulting in  lower and less stable yields.  Herder communities face similar 
issues of low productivity, lack of supplemental income sources, and lack of education.  
 
3.  Rural Electricity Services and Household Consumption. Rural areas in Zhangye City 
face regular load shedding. During power shortages, remote rural areas, which are generally 
serviced through 10-kilovolt distribution lines, are cut off first. Xishui township, where the project 
is located, had power outages for 70 days in 2001 due to load shedding. The power outages 
generally last one or two days. Outages result in electricity being unavailable during critical 
periods of the growing season, according to farmers. Low voltages prevent the usage of 
sensitive appliances, motors, and equipment (e.g., x-ray machines in clinics) or may damage 
equipment due to voltage fluctuations. Extra cost is required for voltage stabilizers. The average 
electricity consumption of poor households is generally very low.
